a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: This is a partial draft of "Note at End of Complete Poems and Prose," which was published in Complete Poems & Prose (1888) and not reprinted during Whitman's lifetime. No image of the manuscript's verso is available.

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: [Seems to me I may]
bibl.orgName: The Walt Whitman Collection, Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center, The University of Texas at Austin
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

body.p: Seems to me I may dare to claim a deep native tap-root for mythe book too, in some sort. I cam on the stage ‸too late for personally knowing much of even the lingering Revolutionary worthies—the men of '76—yet as a little boy I have been press'd tightly and lovingly to the breast of Lafayette (Brooklyn, 1825) and have talked with old Aaron Burr and also with those who knew Washington and his surroundings and with original Jeffersonians, and more than one very old soldier and sailor. And in my own day and maturity my eyes have seen and ears heard, Lincoln, Grant and Emerson, and my hands ‸have been grasp'd by their hands. Though in a different field and range from most of theirs, I give the foregoing pages as perfectly legitimate resultant, evolutionary, and consistent with them ‸If these lines should ever reach some reader of a far off future age, let him take them as a missive sent from Abraham Lincoln's fateful agent....Repeating parrot: like what in the preceding divisions has been already said and must serve as a great reason: why of this whole book—1st. That in the main part ofabout pronounc'd events and shows (poems and persons also) is the point of view from which they are view'd and estimated—and 2d. That I willcan not let themy momentous, stormy, peculiar Era of peace and war, these States, these years, to slip away without arresting it some of its specimen events—even its vital breaths—to be portrayed and inscribed from out of the midst of it infrom its own days and nights—not so much forin themselves..(statistically and descriptively our times seemare copiously noted and memorandered with an industrial zeal)—but to give from them, here their flame:like results in imaginative and spiritual suggestiveness ‸as things present themselves to me, at any rate, from the point of view alluded to.
